This project will meet the operational requirements for India's railways."}

{'cdata!': 'The Uttar Pradesh Tubewell Irrigation Project in India will provide financing for the irrigation of water to regions that have insufficient precipitation, which are not within reach of canal irrigation systems. This project will consist of 530 slotted-pipe wells, and 270 strainer wells, which will be drilled to an average depth of 300 to 400 feet, and have an average capacity of 1.5 cusec. It will be equipped with pumps driven by electric motors with power supplied from the State grid system. The general objectives of the program are to increase agricultural production in the State of Uttar Pradesh by providing irrigation water to regions that have insufficient precipitation and are not within the reach of canal irrigation systems. Economically, the project is very attractive and fully justified.'}

{'cdata!': "The Second Port of Calcutta Project in India will provided the financing for the maintenance of the River Hooghly and improvement of the Port of Calcutta. This project includes the purchase of four new dredgers to supplement the existing, the inadequate Commissioners for the Port of Calcutta(CPC) dredging fleet, as well as other vessels to be employed on river conservancy and operational duties. In King George's Dock, the western arm will be extended to provide holding space for four ships, and four dolphin berths for ships undergoing repairs. In Kidderpore Docks a water re-circulation scheme will eliminate the siltation problem in the docks, and the no. 2 swing bridge will be replaced. Additional cranes, fork lift trucks, tractors and trailers are to be provided as a modest addition to the mechanical-handling equipment of the port. This project will provide the means of maintaining a facility vital to the continued growth of the largest and most important economic region in India."}

{'cdata!': 'The Coal Production Project in India will provide financing for the private coal mining industry to expand its production through the import of equipment. This project will consist of spare parts, replacements, and equipment for the expansion of the existing mines. Coal is a basic element in the Indian economy, and must be counted on to play a predominant role in the future development of the country. Although the country has ample coal reserves, the average quality is low.'}

{'cdata!': 'The Road Project for India will provide financing for construction and reconstruction of National Highways and Bombay Expressways. This project will consist of the procurement of the necessary equipment needed for the execution of the works under a technical, and economic study by foreign consultants of the traffic problems of downtown Bombay in connection with the expressways already under construction and the contemplated future expressways and highways in the area. This project will eliminate the major deficiencies in the National Highway system.'}

{'cdata!': 'The Third Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation Project in India will finance a loan to replenish its foreign exchange resources in order to meet the growing demand of its customers for foreign exchange loans. This project will consist of the development of private industry in India by making available medium-term and long-term loans in foreign exchange, to encourage local and foreign private capital participation in such financing, to make equity investments and to assist in the expansion of the Indian capital market. The project was created to assist in the development of private industry in India, to encourage local and foreign private capital participation in its financing, and to assist in the expansion of the Indian capital market.'}

{'cdata!': 'The Fifth Railway Project for India will finance a loan to execute the rehabilitation and improvement program. This project will consist of the procurement of locomotives, spare parts, other railway materials and equipment, and for services connected therewith. This project is essential to the economic development of India.'}

{'cdata!': "The Fourth Railway Project for India updates appraisals previously made in connections with loans made in July 1957 and September 1958 to help finance the Idian Railways' part of the Second Five-Year Plan. Theses appraisals were reported in TO143 and TO190 respectively. It is recommended that consideration be given to a loan of US $50 million equivalent for purchasing railways equipment, materials, and services. A term of twenty years, including a grace period of three years is recommended."}

project_name: Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation of India Credit Project (02)
project_abstract: {'cdata!': "The Second Industrial Credit Project for India provides the Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation (ICICI) a second loan of $10 million to replenish its foreign exchange resources. The ICICI was created to assist in the development of private industry in India, to encourage local and foreign private capital participation in its financing , and to assist in the expansion of the Indian capital market. This report reviews the corporation's past performance, management and organization, and its investment program and financial prospects, as well as presenting the report's conclusions and recommendations."}

{'cdata!': 'This report covers an appraisal of the first stage of the Koyna Hydro-Electric Power project for India which will include; a transmission line to Bombay, and a transmission line south of the project to serve a number of small towns, villages, and their small industries. Stage I, now under construction, will have an installed capacity of 240 MW; Stage II will provide an additional 240 mw, and water storage for irrigation; Stage III will utilize the tailrace waters of the Stage II power plant and irrigation water, and it will add an additional 90 mw. The continually growing demand for power requires the provision of new generating capacity of the magnitude of Koyna and the development of this project is the most economical method of providing the power.'}

{'cdata!': "The Third Railways Project will provide loans to the Government of India to increase the capacity of the Indian Railways. Loans to the equivalent of $90 million were made by the Bank in July 1957 to help finance part of the Second Five-Year Plan. An appraisal was made in Report No. TO143. This is an update of the appraisal. Progress of the Railways' part of the Plan has been satisfactory, while other sectors of the Plan have fallen behind schedule. As a result the shortage of rail transport is less acute now than it was two years ago. The planned increase of capacity has been raised from 47 to 54 million tons, to bring the total freight capacity to 168 million tons by 1961. This is to be accomplished by an adjustment of rolling stock procurement to provide an additional 11,000 freight cars. Changes have been made in the Railways' Plan because of shortages of materials, foreign exchange problems, and rising prices. While these factors have caused shifts of emphasis and rephrasing of some works, and while the final investment in physical terms may be rather less than was planned, the Railways' program remains fundamentally sound."}

{'cdata!': 'This report covers an appraisal of a project for The Third Damodar Valley Power Expansion Project for India. The project will consist of a 150 UV thermal plant, three multipurpose dams, two hydroelectric installations totaling 100 MDW, a barrage and irrigation system, and transmission system facilities. A recent power survey shows that from 1959 until 1962 or 1963 DVC will not be able to run all of the requirements of its area. Additional power will be required primarily by new industries and a railroad electrification program which is included in India in the second five year plan.'}

{'cdata!': "This report is an appraisal of a project for the Modernization and Expansion of the Port of Madras in India. The project will reduce congestion by speeding up the turn round of ships, lower the cost of handling cargo in the port, and increase the overall operating efficiency. Furthermore, it will result in a considerable increase in the port's capacity to handle general cargo, which is necessary to meet the growth in traffic expected during the next ten years. At the end of the construction period, there will still be sufficient reserve capacity in the port to avoid the threat of congestion during peak periods."}

{'cdata!': 'This report covers an appraisal of a project for the Rehabilitation and Improvement of the Port of Calcutta, in India. The project consists of the conversion of several old King Georgets dock berths into three new general cargo berths with transit sheds, ore oil, berth and one laying-up berth. Several berths in Kidderpore dock will also be improved, and the quay walls in twelve other berths reconditioned and strengthened. Electric cranes and lifts, mechanical cargo-handling equipment, two floating cranes, and the existing railroad will be improved along with additional railway equipment acquired. This project will provide improvement of existing equipment which has passed its useful economic life, and improve existing facilities.'}

{'cdata!': "The Second Tata Iron and Steel Project will finance a loan to provide the cost of goods and equipment (including spare parts), supplies and services needed for the Project, which consists of the expansion and modernization of Jamshedpur, which will be designed to increase their capacity to about 2,000,000 long tons of steel ingots and 1,500,000 tons of semi-finished and finished steel products. The development of the coal and iron mines, and other related and ancillary works, are also included. India's demand for steel is growing rapidly, and any increase in domestic supplies will bring important savings in foreign exchange. The expansion of the iron and steel industry will therefore be of considerable benefit to the economy as a whole."}

{'cdata!': 'The Second Railway Project is principally directed to increasing the capacity of the railways to handle additional traffic. Its most important elements are the acquisition of new rolling stock, the doubling of main-line tracks, improvement in yards, and new signalling. A beginning is made on dieselization of some main-line services, and a further important development in motive power is electrification of certain very high density passenger and freight traffic areas.'}

{'cdata!': 'The Second Railway Project is principally directed to increasing the capacity of the railways to handle additional traffic. Its most important elements are the acquisition of new rolling stock, the doubling of main-line tracks, improvement in yards, and new signalling. A beginning is made on dieselization of some main-line services, and a further important development in motive power is electrification of certain very high density passenger and freight traffic areas.'}

project_name: Trombay Thermal Power Station Expansion Project
project_abstract: {'cdata!': 'The Trombay Thermal Power Station Expansion Project provides finance for the addition of a third thermal generating unit, similar in characteristics to the two units now nearing completion, in the Trombay station located on the northeast shore of Bombay harbor. The unit will have a maximum capacity of 62,500 kw in a 50 cycle turbo-generator supplied with steam from a 6000,000 lb/hr boiler. Operation will be at 1250 lb per square inch pressure and at 950 degrees temperature. The plant will be equipped with coal crushing and handling equipment and will primarily use domestic coal from Central India. It will also be equipped to burn fuel oil and by-products from the adjacent Stanvac oil refinery. The latter fuel is now used in the original plant. The project is estimated to cost the equivalent of 14 million. The Bank has been requested to finance the foreign exchange cost, estimated at the equivalent of $9.8 million inclusive of interest during construction. The loan will be for a period of 18 years including a grace period on amortization payments of approximately 3 years. The project, which should be completed in April 1960, will help meet a continuing shortage of power which is particularly acute in the Bombay area pending construction of a large hydro development at Koyna.'}

{'cdata!': 'The Air India Jet Project will provide a loan to Air India, the Indian-flag carrier on world routes. The project includes the purchase of three jets powered by 12 original engines; radio, galley, and other aircraft auxiliaries; 9 spare engines; other initial spares and stores; some overhaul facilities, a test cell and other special equipment; and a flight simulator. Air India needs more aircraft to cope with growing traffic, and might fail to hold its share of the business unless it acquires jets. For these reasons, Air India has just ordered for early 1960 delivery, three Boeing 707 jets of the 420 model which will be powered by four Rolls-Royce Conway engines each. These three planes have the same service potential, roughly 60 million capacity ton miles a year, as ten Super-Constellations. Air India will have sufficient equipment by 1960/61 for flying 120 million capacity ton miles a year compared with 42 million actually flown in 2956/57.'}

{'cdata!': "The Second Indian Iron and Steel Company Expansion Project for India will finance a project to expand the company's steel rolling capacity. The Tata Iron and Steel Company, Limited (TISCO) is engaged in an expansion program primarily designed to increase its capacity to produce steel ingots from 1.1 million tons to two million tons, and its capacity to produce saleable steel from 780,000 to 1.5 million tons per annum. This expansion program consists of four parts: a modernization and expansion program (known as MEP), a program of further expansion (known as the Two Million Ton Program, or TMTP) designed to increase annual capacity to two million tons of ingots and 1.5 million tons of saleable products. This project is of high priority, and the potential benefits are considerable. The increase in output will provide a substantial addition to the amount of domestic steel available to meet the needs of the second five year plan, at a cost greatly below that of imported steel."}

{'cdata!': 'The Tata Iron and Steel Company Expansion and Modernization Project will provide the necessary raw materials which will make it possible to produce steel in India at a very low cost. This expansion program consists of four parts: A modernization, and expansion program (known as "MEP\'), a program of further expansion (known as the two Million Ton Program or "TMTP\'"), designed to increase annual capacity to 2 million tons of ingots and 1.5 million tons of saleable products. The Tata Iron and Steel Co., Ltd. (TISCO) is engaged in an expansion program primarily designed to increase its capacity to produce steel ingots from 1.1 million tons to 2 million tons, and its capacity to produce saleable steel from 780,000 to 1.5 million tons per annum. This project is of high priority, and benefits are very great. The increase in output will provide an important addition to the amount of domestic steel available to meet the needs of India.'}

{'cdata!': "The Second Loan Administration Report for India is a continuation of L162, and will finance a loan which will provide reconstruction for India. This project will consist of railway rehabilitation, agricultural machinery, Bokaro thermal plant, expansion of iron and steel productive capacity, electric power development, flood control, irrigation, and industrial credit and investment This project will provide further improvement for India's economy."}

{'cdata!': "The Appraisal of the Agricultural Machinery Project for India will finance the establishment of India's Agricultural economy. The project will consists of reclamation of 3,000,000 acres; (b) mechanical preparation of a fifth of the reclaimed land; and (c) re-ploughing of land where kans grass reappears. This project will increase food grain production by ten million, and domestic crops which will satisfy the consumption needs for India. Short term measures to improve yields on areas now under cultivation where adequate supplies of moisture are assured, medium term measures, extending over two to seven years, including reclamation of weed infested and virgin lands and deep well irrigation and multi-purpose river development projects."}

{'cdata!': 'Sweden and the Association would jointly finance the total project cost, pari-passu, on a one-to-two ratio. Sweden would thus participate with the equivalent of US$10.6 million and the Association would extend a credit of US$21.2 million equivalent. In broad terms, the joint-financing arrangement would cover expenditures under the project for three main purposes, namely: (a) investments in plant (buildings, furniture, equipment, vehicles) to complete and supplement the GOI pattern in project areas; (b) the nutrition component; and (c) incremental recurrent costs for the innovative parts of the project (the intensive rural component and the Population Centers). C920HEALTH CENTERS'}

project_abstract: {'cdata!': 'The project, which forms part of the Indian Fourth Five-Year Plan (1969-74), would provide some of the transport services required by increasing oil refinery capacity and by rapidly increasing consumption of refined products. The project consists of: (i) the purchase of four crude oil tankers in the 80,000 dwt class for use between the Persian Gulf and Haldia, and (ii) the purchase of two refined oil products tankers in the 20,000 dwt class for the import, export and coastal distribution of refined petroleum products. In addition, shore facilities will be improved and pollution-control equipment installed at Haldia, Cochin and other oil-handling ports. One or more crude oil transfer vessels totalling about 16,000 dwt for use at Haldia will also be provided.'}
